section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes to represent desert friends.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Nobody Hugs a Cactus, we met a lot of friends who tried to stop and talk to Hank. We counted how many friends walked by. Let’s count again.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Page through the book and place a cube on the table each time a new character appears on page.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will practice counting Connecting Cubes like these. I will give you some Connecting Cubes and we are going to pretend that they are our desert friends. Then you’ll count the cubes and say how many there are in all.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Counting Point to and count each Connecting Cube on the table one-by-one. Clearly model touching one cube as you say a number. Explain that it is helpful to arrange the cubes in a way so you know which have and have not been counted.
Ask Hand each child five to ten “desert friends”. Ask children to count aloud one at a time. Say: How many friends in all? Guide children to answer by saying “There are [number of cubes] in all.”
Extend Challenge children to describe how they counted the cubes. If they could count more efficiently, guide them to try a different strategy.
Repeat Give children a different amount of cubes and play again.

Talk About Counting What is important to remember when counting? Review strategies such as counting from one, counting in order, and understanding that the last number said is the total number of objects.
Limit the amount of Connecting Cubes to five or less at a time. Count with each child, guiding their finger as they point to each individual cube.

After children say how many cubes in all, give them one or two more cubes and ask for the updated total. Guide them to realize they don’t have to recount the original set of cubes—they can simply count on.

Review the number words with children before playing. Use the Number Cards to show a numeral and say its name. Then show a dot card with that number of dots. Count the dots aloud and say the total again, while pointing to the numeral on the card.
To help develop children’s fine motor skills, have children trace or draw the numeral representing the total number of Connecting Cubes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes to represent desert friends.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we talked about how Hank shares his emotions with his friends in Nobody Hugs a Cactus. We already counted out the friends in the book using Connecting Cubes.

In this activity, we will practice sharing and counting Connecting Cubes. I will give each pair some desert friend cubes to count. One partner will count the cubes and the other partner will say how many cubes there are in all. Then you’ll trade and I’ll give you a different amount of cubes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Pick a child to act as your partner. Model touching each cube as you count aloud. Ask your partner to say how many cubes in all. Remind children that it is helpful to arrange the cubes so you know which have been counted.
Set Up Give varying amounts of Connecting Cubes to each pair.
Ask Have partner A count out the cubes one at a time. Guide partner B to say “There are [number of cubes] in all.”
Repeat Give each pair a different amount of cubes. Partner B counts the cubes and partner A says how many cubes in all.
Extend Have children work as a pair to count the cubes all together.

Talk About Managing Emotions Praise children for the good job they did sharing the cubes and working together. Sometimes it is hard to stay calm when playing a game or sharing with a friend. Did you have to manage your emotions as we played today? What did you do?

Some children may become frustrated waiting for their turn to count. Review different ways to manage emotions that have been discussed and choose a strategy together, like breathing slowly and deeply to calm themselves as they wait.

Give children 8–10 Connecting Cubes. After they count the cubes, take three cubes away and challenge them to tell how many cubes are left without counting. Guide them to check by counting the cubes aloud.

Multilingual learners may have trouble during the discussion about managing emotions. Encourage them to use words from their home language or gestures to help communicate their stories of struggling with sharing their emotions.

Small group discussions often feel less intimidating to children who feel uncomfortable speaking in the large group. Encourage these quieter children to share more and speak up in the discussion and when working with a partner.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need 10 Connecting Cubes in a bag and the Lala Stick Puppet.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In Nobody Hugs a Cactus, we read about a cactus named Hank that lives all alone in the desert. Today, we’re going to play a game with pretend desert plants.
In this activity, we are going to help Lala make sure that our desert plants are NOT alone. Lala will ask for a number of desert plants. You will count out that number of “plants.”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Counting As Lala, ask for five desert plants. Count aloud as you take out five cubes one at a time. Set each cube on the table as you count. When you are done, say, There are five cubes in all.
Ask As Lala, ask, Please give me four desert plants.
Have one child count out four cubes from the bag. Guide the child to place them on the table and say how many desert plants there are in all. Then ask the child to return the cubes to the bag.
Repeat Have the puppet ask the next child for a different number of desert plants from the bag. Continue with different numbers between two and 10 until each child has a turn.
Extend Ask children how they knew when to stop counting. If necessary, guide children to try a more efficient counting strategy.
Talk About Totals Remind children that the last number counted is the total, or number of cubes in all. Ask children to share how they know when they are done counting.

Encourage children to recount the cubes after they place all of the cubes on the table. Did they count to the same number both times? If needed, count along with the children as they count cubes out of the bag, then guide them to recount the cubes alone.

Allow children to play with each other. Give partner A a puppet and give partner B the bag of cubes. After partner B counts out the number of cubes requested by partner A, partner A checks by counting those cubes aloud. Then have children switch roles.

Pair native-English speakers with children who are not native-English speakers to increase children’s exposure to both languages. If needed, have the non-native English speaker repeat each number after the native-English speaker.
Fine Motor Development
Have children recount the set of cubes they placed on the table using a pointer, like a ruler or pencil. Guide children to point to each cube as they count it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes and a folder, book, or other object to use as a curtain.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we matched up feelings with faces that showed those feelings. We also counted out letters. Now we are going to combine counting and matching up!

I will place a number of cubes on my side of this curtain. I will tell you the number of cubes I used. You will put the same number of cubes on your side of the curtain. When you are done, I’ll lift the curtain and we will check that we have the same number of cubes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Place three cubes behind the curtain. Announce that you have three cubes behind the curtain. Guide children to count out three cubes on their side of the curtain. Lift the curtain. Have the entire group help you count each set and confirm the number of cubes matches.
Set Up Place between one and ten cubes behind your curtain. Start with five.
Ask Can you match five? Ask one child to count out five cubes. Lift the curtain. As a group, count the cubes aloud on each side to make sure both sides match.
Repeat Continue the game until each child has had a chance to count out cubes behind the curtain at least twice.
Talk About Matching Have children discuss how they knew the amounts on each side of the curtain were the same, even though they may have been arranged differently.

Help children count out the cubes on their side of the curtain, and then let them count the cubes on your side. Encourage them to point to each cube as they count, and rearrange them as needed to keep track of which they have already counted.

Have children compare the cubes from both sides of the curtain on their own rather than with you. Encourage them to try different counting strategies and to explain why the totals are the same even when they are arranged differently.
Review the number words with children before playing. As you count out loud from one to 10, show number cards with the corresponding numbers or use your fingers to represent each number.
Speech Support
If children struggle to pronounce some of the words during the discussion, help them by saying the word one syllable at a time. Have them repeat the syllables slowly, and then put them together.
